text: @Iorec, I don't anything about Matrix but if it garbles edited replies and doesn't support replying to threads, you should join Slack instead. What I said before is, my stuff is also based on .NET, and due to my area of research (see <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Eqm2Eip884E> and <http://ecsharp.net|ecsharp.net> and <http://core.loyc.net|core.loyc.net>) I am curious what you use as a serialization format for vvvv "source code". Can you output the vvvv program as C# code, or as an assembly DLL that can be consumed by C#/VB programs?

elements.text: @Iorec, I don't anything about Matrix but if it garbles edited replies and doesn't support replying to threads, you should join Slack instead. What I said before is, my stuff is also based on .NET, and due to my area of research (see
) I am curious what you use as a serialization format for vvvv "source code". Can you output the vvvv program as C# code, or as an assembly DLL that can be consumed by C#/VB programs?

text: <@UD6EXQVM0>: we're currently using xml but not happy with it. wanted to investigate moving to yml instead at some point. and yes, we're using roslyn to generate c# code from our visual code that we then compile to executables when someone exports their program. easy DLL export is not yet realized but planned. and via the c# export you could already compile a DLL yourself

elements.text: : we're currently using xml but not happy with it. wanted to investigate moving to yml instead at some point. and yes, we're using roslyn to generate c# code from our visual code that we then compile to executables when someone exports their program. easy DLL export is not yet realized but planned. and via the c# export you could already compile a DLL yourself
